B00023B1LM|3.0|Just about every Alfred Hitchcock film involved an innocent and everyday man caught up in some plot where he doesn't know what is going on or how to save himself from it.  The Bourne Identity modernises this method.  There's more action, and instead of an everyman in the lead role, we instead have a deadly assassin who doesn't know what he is because he has amnesia as a result of being shot and left for dead.  We follow Jason Bourne as he tries to figure out who and what he is while simultaneously trying to stay alive. <br /> <br />There are a lot of things to like about this film.  The mystery is interesting - we know more about Jason than he does himself, because we see his (former) employers at work, but that only helps keep the plot moving.  I especially like how the action scenes leap out of nowhere - the film turns from exposition or mystery solving to violent, brutish action in seconds.  Finally, the acting and characterisation by the main characters is great - Matt Damon is good as always.  He has a Harrison Ford-like quality of being able to appear frightened and highly competent simultaneously.  He is joined by Franka Potente (little known in America except from \\"Run Lola Run\\") who does a very good job in the thankless role of the innocent girl caught up for the ride. <br /> <br />The film straddles the line between mystery-thriller and action film.  The two parts blend seamlessly.  Unfortunately, there are a number of little things that pull the film's overall enjoyability down.  Most annoying is the plot surrounding the assassination attempts on an ex-dictator.  Firstly, the dictator is portrayed as a scenery-mashing, bug-eyed monster in a performance that is jarringly out of place in a film of subtlety.  Secondly, there is confusion surrounding the second assassination attempt.  We see in the newspaper the next day that it was successful, but we know (because we saw it) that it wasn't.  What's the dictator's game?  Is he faking his death to escape further attempts?  Is there a cut scene later on where we would have seen him assassinated?  The story leaves this dangling, and it's annoying.  Secondly, when Bourne bribes an official, he uses American money.  Since the action takes place in Paris, why doesn't he use Euros?  Because some people in an American audience wouldn't recognise them?  In a movie that prides itself on being smart, this is a glaring error.  Thirdly, there seems to be no rationale for the CIA to be trying to assassinate Bourne (as opposed to capturing him to find out what happened). <br /> <br />While you're watching the film, most would not notice these problems, but upon thinking about it afterwards, you feel like the film was only good and not great.  Another example - if the car chase had taken place in New York instead of Paris, and had Bourne's car been a Lincoln Towncar instead of a Mini, the car chase would not be very interesting.  But it's only on hindsight that these questions arise.  All-in-all, it's a fun and interesting movie, of high quality, as evidenced in the performances of Damon and Potente. <br /> <br />The DVD has a few extras like deleted scenes and a director's commentary.  The sound and video are good (as expected).

B00001OH7P|5.0|I was first exposed to David Bowie from his greatest hits album, \\"Best Of Bowie\\". Although I enjoyed several tracks on the record, it left me puzzled to who the man behind the glam was. When first listening to \\"The Rise & Fall of Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders From Mars\\", the pieces of the puzzle start to come together. Bowie is yet another artist destine for albums, and not greatest hits compilations. Which is the reason that discovering this masterpiece is more worthwhile than just listening to his hits. It's a loosely based concept album the centers around an alien rock star named Ziggy Stardust. The music is very mnemonic, and ominous. It's loud, and very thick in arrangement which includes string sections, keyboards, and stellar guitar work. The record sounds incredibly unique, mostly due to the fantastic theatrical feel to the album. This album epitomized glam upon it's perfect execution.<br /><br />Just about every song here is a classic. Although \\"Starman\\" was the only charted single (peaking at 65), others have received airplay upon it's notable cult classic status, which includes two infectious rockers, \\"Ziggy Stardust\\" and \\"Suffragette City\\", which run back to back towards the end of the album. Although, I'd have to say my favorite is \\"Lady Stardust\\".<br /><br />This record is simply a stunning change of pace for me, which is why I love it. It just spews with originality. The concept, the lyrics, and the intense sound makes for quite the rewarding listen. If you are a first time purchaser of Bowie's, screw \\"The Best of Bowie\\" and check this out. You'll thank me and everyone who tells you the same later.
B000AU9UYC|5.0|Before this movie, Batman had never really been accurately portrayed on the silver screen. But, now he has...  This IS the definitive Batman film.  Not only is it a great superhero/action film - it is a wonderful film in general.<br /><br />Batman Begins is a reboot for the Batman movie franchise; it is in no way linked to the previous 4 movies in any way (and thankfully, in my opinion).  It is an origin story of one of America's most popular characters and it delves into the character of the Dark Knight in ways that have not been seen on the silver screen before.<br /><br />We \\"begin\\" with a young Bruce Wayne and get a feel for the wonderful, loving childhood he had until his parents were tragically murdered in front of his own eyes by a bum on the streets of Gotham.  We then follow a grown up Bruce all around the world as he learns what it is like to live without a home or money and as he seeks the means to fighting injustice some time after the death of his parents.  We learn why it is that he chooses to become a man dressed like a giant bat and how he acquires the weapons and technology needed to fight the criminals of Gotham and to restore peace to his beloved city.  Even the functionality of every part of the suit from the cape to the ears on the cowl is explained.  That's just a glimpse of the attention to detail that this movie takes into allowing us to know this character.<br /><br />Also, we really get to know Bruce Wayne in Begins.  He really has such a great character arc and we really feel for the character long before he ever dons the cape and cowl. Bruce Wayne/Batman is clearly the central character in this movie, which the previous live-action films failed to accomplish.<br /><br />The cast in the film is superb.  Christian Bale does an incredible job as Bruce Wayne and Batman.  As many know, these are really two different parts because Bruce Wayne is really the fake, public persona wheras Batman is when Bruce Wayne shows his true identity.  They finally touch on this, and it is done beautifully.  Also, Gary Oldman is wonderful as Lt. Jim Gordon - and thankfully this character is done in such an awesome fashion.  He is Batman's only friend and a great cop on a terribly corrupt police force in this movie, the way the character was meant to be.  Michael Caine really shines as Alfred and the character is portrayed wonderfully.  Liam Neeson is spectacular (as always) as Henri Ducard, Bruce Wayne's mentor.  Cillian Murphy is wonderfully twisted and creepy as the Scarecrow without being over the top whatsoever.  And Morgan Freeman's performance is great (as always) in the few memorable scenes he is in.  Katie Holmes also really gives a great performance as Bruce's lifetime friend and Gotham Assistant DA.<br /><br />As far as the plot goes - it is fantastic.  You are really drawn into this movie for its entirety.  Christopher Nolan and David Goyer wrote a great script with an incredibly touching and suspensful plot.  Nolan also directed flawlessly.  The action scenes are really incredible as well, and all of the action is necessary to the plot and extremely well edited.<br /><br />One of the most wonderful things about this movie is the realism that is consistent throughout the movie.  Gone are the ridiculous neon lights of Schumacher's movies and the extreme Gothic tone of Burton's.  You really feel that Batman could exist in this Gotham City - even so much that this movie doesn't feel like a \\"superhero\\" movie.  It really goes above and beyond the genre to create a very realistic movie that all audiences can thoroughly enjoy and appreciate at the same time.  It may be a little bit on the scary side for younger kids - but there is hardly any objectional content in this movie otherwise (which I greatly appreciate).<br /><br />This movie is a MUST SEE, in my opinion, and a MUST OWN for anyone who likes having great movies to watch any time.  Check this one out.  It is an extremely fine film, and one of my favorites thatI have ever seen.
B00005QDW5|5.0|It doesn't take a rocket scientist to know that Pink Floyd is one of the greatest rock bands ever. Creating some of the finest albums ever made (including the greatest album ever, \\"Dark Side Of The Moon\\"), they have carved a pretty impressive niche in rock history. They are also one of the few bands who, in order to have all their best songs, buy all of their albums. However, there are actually some people in the world who only want one Floyd album in their collection.<br /><br />In 2001, those casual fans' prayers were answered with the two cd, 26 track collection \\"Echoes: The Very Best Of Pink Floyd\\". Featuring tracks compiled and sequenced by the band members, this cd does indeed top previous Floyd collections such as \\"A Collection Of Great Dance Songs\\". But how does it add up overall? Here are the positives and the negatives.<br /><br />Positives:<br /><br />-As I said, no compilation will ever truly capture all of Pink Floyd's best. But if you only want one Floyd cd iny our collection (though I can't imagine why one would), than you've come to the right place. \\"Echoes\\" contains all the Floyd classics casual fans will recognize, including \\"Another Brick In The Wall\\", \\"The Great Gig In The Sky\\", \\"Money\\", \\"Shine On You Crazy Diamond (Parts 1 - 7)\\", \\"Time\\", \\"Comfortably Numb\\", \\"Us And Them\\" and \\"Wish You Were Here\\".<br /><br />-All the tracks ound superb with the digital remastering job.<br /><br />-Though it is not in chronological order, the collection flows well.<br /><br />-They included \\"The Fletcher Memorial Home\\", just about the only listenable thing on \\"The Final Cut\\".<br /><br />-You get some Syd Barret numbers. This is great, since I have been interested in hearing the song \\"Arnold Layne\\", a song about a kleptomaniac transvestite.<br /><br />-The booklet is beautiful<br /><br />Negatives:<br /><br />-\\"Money\\" sounds unnatural without seguing into \\"Us And Them\\".<br /><br />-The band's magnum opuses, \\"Echoes\\" and \\"Shine On You Crazy Diamond\\", are both edited. Both were over 20 minutes, but they are cut down to 16 minutes and 17 minutes, respectively.<br /><br />-There are many omissions, but one tops them all: where is \\"Speak To Me/Breathe\\"?! That song really should've been here.<br /><br />-While you're on the subject of omissions, where's \\"Careful With That Axe, Eugene\\", \\"Atom Heart Mother\\", \\"Eclipse\\", \\"Welcome To The Machine\\", \\"Have A Cigar\\", \\"Pigs On The Wing\\", \\"Run Like Hell\\"... the list goes on.<br /><br />-As well as this collection is sequenced, it should have been done chronologically.<br /><br />So, how does this collection hold up? Surprisingly well. If you're a casual fan, this collection will be perfect. And even if you have all their albums, the sound alone makes \\"Echoes\\" worth owning. B00005JNJV|5.0|Before this movie, Batman had never really been accurately portrayed on the silver screen. But, now he has...  This IS the definitive Batman film.  Not only is it a great superhero/action film - it is a wonderful film in general.<br /><br />Batman Begins is a reboot for the Batman movie franchise; it is in no way linked to the previous 4 movies in any way (and thankfully, in my opinion).  It is an origin story of one of America's most popular characters and it delves into the character of the Dark Knight in ways that have not been seen on the silver screen before.<br /><br />We \\"begin\\" with a young Bruce Wayne and get a feel for the wonderful, loving childhood he had until his parents were tragically murdered in front of his own eyes by a bum on the streets of Gotham.  We then follow a grown up Bruce all around the world as he learns what it is like to live without a home or money and as he seeks the means to fighting injustice some time after the death of his parents.  We learn why it is that he chooses to become a man dressed like a giant bat and how he acquires the weapons and technology needed to fight the criminals of Gotham and to restore peace to his beloved city.  Even the functionality of every part of the suit from the cape to the ears on the cowl is explained.  That's just a glimpse of the attention to detail that this movie takes into allowing us to know this character.<br /><br />Also, we really get to know Bruce Wayne in Begins.  He really has such a great character arc and we really feel for the character long before he ever dons the cape and cowl. Bruce Wayne/Batman is clearly the central character in this movie, which the previous live-action films failed to accomplish.<br /><br />The cast in the film is superb.  Christian Bale does an incredible job as Bruce Wayne and Batman.  As many know, these are really two different parts because Bruce Wayne is really the fake, public persona wheras Batman is when Bruce Wayne shows his true identity.  They finally touch on this, and it is done beautifully.  Also, Gary Oldman is wonderful as Lt. Jim Gordon - and thankfully this character is done in such an awesome fashion.  He is Batman's only friend and a great cop on a terribly corrupt police force in this movie, the way the character was meant to be.  Michael Caine really shines as Alfred and the character is portrayed wonderfully.  Liam Neeson is spectacular (as always) as Henri Ducard, Bruce Wayne's mentor.  Cillian Murphy is wonderfully twisted and creepy as the Scarecrow without being over the top whatsoever.  And Morgan Freeman's performance is great (as always) in the few memorable scenes he is in.  Katie Holmes also really gives a great performance as Bruce's lifetime friend and Gotham Assistant DA.<br /><br />As far as the plot goes - it is fantastic.  You are really drawn into this movie for its entirety.  Christopher Nolan and David Goyer wrote a great script with an incredibly touching and suspensful plot.  Nolan also directed flawlessly.  The action scenes are really incredible as well, and all of the action is necessary to the plot and extremely well edited.<br /><br />One of the most wonderful things about this movie is the realism that is consistent throughout the movie.  Gone are the ridiculous neon lights of Schumacher's movies and the extreme Gothic tone of Burton's.  You really feel that Batman could exist in this Gotham City - even so much that this movie doesn't feel like a \\"superhero\\" movie.  It really goes above and beyond the genre to create a very realistic movie that all audiences can thoroughly enjoy and appreciate at the same time.  It may be a little bit on the scary side for younger kids - but there is hardly any objectional content in this movie otherwise (which I greatly appreciate).<br /><br />This movie is a MUST SEE, in my opinion, and a MUST OWN for anyone who likes having great movies to watch any time.  Check this one out.  It is an extremely fine film, and one of my favorites thatI have ever seen.

B00006JIA4|4.0|In 1971 one four talented musicians (Freddie Mercury, Brian May, John Deacon, and Roger Taylor) came together and formed one of the greatest rock bands of all time . . . Queen.  Not only was Queen one of the best bands of the 70s they were also one of the most controversial and notorious bands of that time.  With songs such as, Fat Bottomed Girls, Bicycle Race, and Don't Stop Me (along with Freddie's borderline approach in the sexual realm), Queen became one of those bands that moms didn't want their kids to have, and probably for good reason.  However, if a kid was lucky enough to get his hands on a Queen album (and many, many, many were) he was almost assured of playing that record until it could play no more.  So anyway, back to my review of the Platinum Collection.  As one can probably guess by now, I absolutely love Queen, however that does not mean that I absolutely love this collection.  The first cd of this collection is absolutely amazing; there's not a weak selection on the whole thing.  Starting out with Bohemian Rhapsody, a true masterpiece, it concludes with one of the bands most famous hits, We Are The Champions.  Sandwiched in-between these two songs are all of Queens' biggest and best hits (Another One Bites the Dust, Killer Queen, Fat Bottomed Girls, Bicycle Race, My Best Friend, We Will Rock You . . . they're all here).  The collection than moves into the second cd, Greatest Hits Volume II, which is a very, very strong compilation of most of Queen's lesser chart hits (such as, One Vision, which charted at #61),   big chart hits from the bands later years (such as Radio Ga Ga, which charted at #16 in 1984 and The Show Must Go On, which charted at #16 in the U.K. in 1991), and several fan favorites (such as Innuendo, Breakthru, and I Want it All).  While not as good as the first cd in this set, Greatest Hits Volume II will makes its way into your car's cd player quite often.  I wish my review could be over now, having covered two excellent cds, but no there is one more \\"bonus\\" cd that this collection offers.  The bonus cd, unlike Greatest Hits Volumes I and II, will not get frequent play time in your car stereo system, or any other stereo system for that matter.  When I first listened to this cd I thought to myself why even bother and I haven't listened to it since.  The third cd in the set (Greatest Hits Volume III) is basically a waste of time and money.  Most of the songs on it, are artists (i.e. Elton John, George Michael, and more) trying to cover classic Queen hits.  Seriously, only Freddie Mercury (Queen's lead singer) can sing Queen songs the way they are meant to be sung, and once he passed away Queen really should have just stopped altogether (It's like the Doors without Jim Morrison).  Anyway, this cd is a pointless addition to the collection.  If I were you, which I am not, I would go out and buy Queen's Greatest Hits Volumes I and II, two disc compilation, forget Greatest Hits Volume III, its not worth the extra $5-10.  In conclusion, Queen was a great band, and Greatest Hits Volumes I and II captures most of their best work - they are perfect cds for a person just starting to listen to Queen or an avid fan who is looking to bolster his collection.  Believe me, once you buy Greatest Hits Volume I, you better put it on your computer hard-drive right away, because you are going to play that thing until it can't play anymore.   <br /> <br />P.S.  The Platinum Connection contains an excellent mini-booklet, that gives a brief story behind the songs (including chart positions) and provides excellent photos of Queen covers and of the band itself.    <br />

B0009I7NNA|4.0|I'd seen this band's name listed in the club show directory a few times in the past, but beyond that, I knew nothing about them.  When I heard \\"Bat Country\\" on the radio a week ago, I knew I had to buy this CD.   <br /> <br />For starters, the fact that this band actually has a lead guitarist who knows how to play the guitar sets them head and shoulders above most other so-called \\"nu-metal\\" bands.  With finger-tapping, hammer-ons, harmonics; and all that other good stuff, Avenged Sevenfold have more in common with bands like Shadows Fall, Slayer, and Children of Bodom, and classic German metallers Helloween, then with modern crap-metal bands like Papa Roach and Slipknot. <br /> <br />\\"The Beast and the Harlot\\" is a great opening track that really sets the pace for the rest of the album.  It shreds, and again, the lead guitar is outstanding(the lead guitarist is named \\"Synyster Gates\\").  There are some nice acoustic flourishes on this CD, and the previously mentioned \\"Bat Country\\" is a real standout(an ode to drug addiction, and an obvious reference to \\"Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas\\").  There's also \\"Betrayed\\"; a rather powerful tribute to late Pantera guitarist Dimebag Darrel.   <br /> <br />Why did this album only get 4 stars? For one, despite the above average musicianship, there's not really a ton of variety in terms of the pacing and intensity of the tracks.  This band doesn't do acoustic or subtle very well, so when those tracks appear, they don't provide a truly compelling contrast.  That's something that can change as they continue to develop as a band.  Also, the singer, while strong in his lower range, sounds a bit too nasally in his higher range; almost like a wannabe Mike Patton on Faith No More's \\"The Real Thing\\".  Again, he's good in his lower range; just for future reference, watch the nasally thing!  <br /> <br />Anyway, this is a good CD, and I recommend it.  Much better than most of the so-called \\"nu-metal\\" trash out there now.  This band has a tonof potential, and has given me hope that there are young musicians in America who still know how to play the guitar.

I mean, Jeff Bridge's Dude, well, 'it's just good to know he's out there,' as the film's cowboy narrator quips laconically at the bar. The characters are brilliantly conceived cliches: the middle-aged detritus of the 60s. 'Metallica' roadie(Bridges) and Vietnam vet(Goodman) contend with big money racketeers of the 90s. There's the stony performance artist(Moore) who wants a baby donor without the encumbrance of a husband, a porn star nympho married to the geriatric cripple Lubowski, whose suspect alliance is the cause of a kidnapping scam. It's all comic-strip speed and synchronised to the cannonading commotion of the bowling alley. Oh the cameos! The snake-hipped Jesus bowler strutting at the head of the lane(Turturro), and the whippet-faced loser, Donny(Busconi). The Dude's flashbacks induced by weed, kelhua, knockout beltings or acid flashbacks, are brilliant. The story is preposterous, but we, like the Dude, just roll with the punches. Goodman's dementia is one of his finest screen acts. His final folly, first piling the memory of Donny onto the corpse of his Vietnam experience, then allowing the Pacific updraft to dowse the Dude in their deceased mate's ashes, is a hoot. Goodman stands pathetically knock-kneed, trying to make up to the Dude with a cuddle that he knows is appropriate but is too repressed to enjoin. Damn it. Let's go bowling!

And with that album they stick it to the man. B0007OCG4W|4.0|Based on the original play by Patrick Marber, Mike Nichols delivers an interesting adaptation which only flaw seems to be that play like feeling in some parts of the movie.  `Closer' tells the story of four people whose lives get connected to one another's in the most dysfunctional ways.<br /><br />I had never seen a movie about relationships that portrayed so realistically all the ups and downs. The movie opens with Dan and Alice meeting and falling in love in a quite traditional and romantic way, with the beautiful `Blower's daughter' in the background. Going from there we get to see a story of betrayal and a well earned lack of trust in the relationships of these four characters. I won't give away the plot like many other reviewers already did, but these characters are lovable even when they have no respect for anything, even when they break the hearts of the ones that love them.<br /><br />The approach to relationships in this story is crude and erotic, there are situations in which the dialogues will just blow you away, and these moments are mostly because of the well chosen cast and a very good direction. Jude Law, Natalie Portman, Clive Owen and even Julia Roberts deliver some  moments that are sometimes hard to digest and/or believe, the discussions and the openness of the things they say one another are great contributions to the story.<br /><br />Like said before, the only apparent flaw this movie has is the use of the timeframes, one moment you are watching a regular sequence and in the next cut a year has passed already, with no explanation at all, you will have to guess based on the situations and the subtle changes perceived (forget about titles saying `One year later', there's nothing of that here) This situation can make it difficult to some people to watch and understand completely the film. Other than that, the direction, photography and performance of the cast are breathtaking.<br /><br />The movie has no extras at all (I do not consider previews for other films as extras, hope you agree) besides Damien Rice's music video for `The Blower's daughter', which will be enough for fans of the film. B00005JNSK|3.0|It's been a long long LONG time since I've read the book, so naturally, my comparisons here are between the first movie and this newer version.    I think I would give the original movie a B+ and this one a B. Like they say, if something ain't broke, don't fix it. Here's what's broken in the new version:    1.) No subplot involving Mr. Slugworth trying to get an everlasting gobstopper out of the kids. This provided an epiphany at the end of the original that is sadly missed here. That subplot was great because it showed us that Charlie was indeed a good person, by the fact that he gave the gobstopper to Mr. Wonka even after being told he \\"gets nothing!\\".  This subplot wasn't in the book, so it's easy to forgive Burton for deviating here.    2.) No fizzy lifting drink tangent for Charlie and his grandfather, which furthered the subplot above (again, this wasn't in the book either).    3.) Introduction to Charlie, his family and his search for a golden ticket does seem to go on forever....Next thing we know, Augustus is getting sucked into the chocolate spaceship tube. The whole factory tour seems a bit rushed.    4.) First oompa loompa song rocks, and you start to think that this is the point where the movie will start to crackle. However, subsequent oompa loompa songs aren't as good as the first and maybe two out of the four are catchy and/or funny. The casting of Deep Roy (whoever he is) as the oompa loompas, however, is definitely a positive.    5.) Varuca's demise: Here it involved squirrels and \\"bad nuts\\" as opposed to golden geese and varuca being a \\"bad egg\\". 1971 idea was much funnier (not to mention the original song, \\"I want today, I want tomorrow\\"), but the book apparently had squirrels--I am guessing the 1971 movie couldn't pull this off as far as the F/X department goes).    6.) Johnny Depp looks WAY too young to be an aging chocolate factory owner seeking an \\"heir\\" to his chocolate throne.  He also reminds us WAY too much of a certain King of Pop.    7.) Ending is a major let down (spoiler alert!), the way Charlie is unceremoniouly the winner just because he is the last of the four standing. Then the movie goes off on a tangent where Charlie and Willie to visit Willie's dad to reconcile old issues. That whole ending won't interest kids, and frankly as an adult, I didn't care either.    8.) Other differences that don't matter much: Violet is escorted by her mother in this film (her father was in the first movie), Mike Teavee is escorted by his father here (his frantic mother was in the first movie).    All that being said, it is still a fun trip, with probably more laughs than the original.  Worth the ticket, and would probably be fun to see at the IMAX theaters it has been showing in.
B0009S4IHY|4.0|In 2004, Stephen Chow directed, co-produced, co-wrote and starred in the imaginative kung fu film named \\"Kung Fu Hustle\\".  The fictional story is set in China probably before the Japanese invasion in the city of Shanghai.  A ruthless black-suited gang, known as the Axe Gang, controls the police and spreads terror where ever it is in control.  It also thrives financially on casinos. However, the Axe Gang (and other less influential gangs) tend to ignore the poorest areas, including a little-known set of dilapidated apartments and shops known as Pig Sty Town.  Its landlord (Wah Yuen) and extremely loud landlady (Qiu Yuen) often fight with each other and make frequent calls and demands upon their poor renters.  One day, two men claiming to be part of the Axe Gang pass through Pig Sty Town.  The two men, Sing (Stephen Chow) and his sidekick (Chi Chung Lam) try to bully themselves with the poor Pig Sty Town residents, but are quickly thwarted by the noisy landlady.  In at attempt to call for help, Sing shoots a firework beyond the walls of Pig Sty Town and it happens to land upon the head of a real Axe Gang boss, who is traveling with a dozen or more black-suited gang members and immediately demand to know who attacked them.  Amazingly, three of Pig Sty Town's poor residents attack the gang with heroic kung fu fighting.  Angered, The Axe Gang leader, Brother Sum (Kwok Kuen Chan), hires two kung fu masters to attack Pig Sty Town.  He also makes Sing an offer: if he can prove himself by killing someone, he can join the Axe Gang; but Sing and his sidekick can't quite be as evil as they would like, especially when they encounter a mute young woman (Si Lu Ren?) and her ice cream stand.  Using an unusual stringed instrument filled with weapons, the two kung fu masters (Kang Xi Jia and Hak On Fung) attack the three poor Pig Sty Town residents that have superb martial arts skills, while the landlady screams at them from above to keep quiet.  The two kung fu masters are very good until they the landlord and landlady come out to confront them.  The Axe Gang then decides to recruit a very powerful kung fu master known only as The Beast (Hsiao Liang), who is located in a mental health asylum.  The Beast brings out the truth about who the landlord and landlady are, but Sing may discover things about himself as well.<br /><br />With interesting kung fu choreography enhanced with computer-generated special effects and humor, \\"Kung Fu Hustle\\" is entertaining, but some people may find some parts of it a bit too violent.  If you enjoy kung fu films, then you will probably enjoy this entertaining kung fu fantasy by Stephen Chow.  Overall, I rate the film with 4 out of 5 stars.  Other interesting characters include Rabbit-Tooth Jane (Kai Shi Chen), Donut (Zhi Hua Dong), Coolie (Yu Xing), the Axe Gang Advisor (Kai Man Tin), the Tailor (Chi Ling Chiu), the Axe Gang Vice General (Suet Lam) and the Crocodile Gang Boss (Xiaogang Feng).until they the landlord and landlady come out to confront them. B000024D4R|4.0|This isn't really a review for the album, but it is something a little different...         During the tour for Animals in 1977, the \\"In the Flesh\\" tour, Pink Floyd played this album in its entirety.  After a short break they played the entire Wish You Were Here album and the song Money was the encore for the entire tour.  On one occasion they also added Us and Them to the encore. On one date, because the band was please that the audience actually listened to the music through out the show, they played Money, Us and Them, and Careful With that Axe Eugene (they hadn't played this song in years and it would be the last time they would ever play it live). A bootleg of this show is available on eBay.         During the final show of the tour in Montreal - the infamous show where Roger spat at a guy in the audience which became one of the factors leading to concept for The Wall -  Roger refused to come out for the encore so second quitarist Snowy White switched to bass for Money.         Although they played the entire Animals album, they changed the song order (due to time constraints, they could not have put this sequence on the original vinyl - the 8-track, for those who remember that format, is another story).     As there isn't an official live release of the tour; you can get an idea of what went on by sequencing the tracks as follows:    IN THE FLESH tour    1. Sheep  2. Pigs On The Wing (Part 1)  3. Dogs  4. Pigs On The Wing (Part 2)  5. Pigs (Three Different Ones)    break (go get yourself a drink or use the litter box)    6. Wish You Were Here (entire album as is)    encore    7. Money     8. Us and Then (if you were really good)      PLAY LOUD!!      P.S. I give this album 4 stars becouse Dogs is not one of my favorite songs. B000002C1W|4.0|Much to the suprise, and delight, of Pink Floyd fans \\"A Momentary Lapse of Reason\\" was released in 1987 sans Roger Waters. Now that time has passed, and so has the novelty, it seems Pink Floyd fans are more than eager to criticize this disc. Some even have the audacity to call it a fraud, or as Roger Waters summed it up \\"a pretty fair forgery\\". I disagree. <br /> <br />I'll be the first to admit that the record does sound more like a David Gilmour & studio musicians album than it does Pink Floyd. Nonetheless, tell me what sounds better--David Gilmour & studio musicians or Roger Waters & studio musicians (i.e. \\"The Final Cut\\"). I rest my case.  <br /> <br />The record is pretty solid. The only complaint I really have is that David Gilmour should have waited to get Rick Wright fully back in the band before he started this record. Although fans are often quick to complain about a lack of Roger Waters, it seems few fans really appreciate Rick Wright. He alone truly adds the atmosphere and mood to Pink Floyd's music. Compare this record to \\"Division Bell\\" and you can see the difference. The latter has more of the Pink Floyd sound because you can here the interplay between Gilmour, Mason & Wright and less of the programmed sequenced synthasizers that dominate this disc. <br /> <br />All that being said, it is, despite any of its shortcomings, a great record. It contains of course the radio hits \\"Learning to Fly\\" and \\"On the Turning Away\\", but like any Pink Floyd record, there are more than just the radio songs. In my opinion \\"Yet Another Movie\\" and \\"Sorrow\\" and just as strong, if not stronger, songs. Even better is we are once again treated to Pink Floyd instrumentals. \\"Signs of Life\\" and \\"Terminal Frost\\" stand as probably the most evocative and emotional songs on the record. The only song that I can honestly say I don't care for is \\"The Dogs of War\\" and even that is not horrible, it is just not my cup of tea.  <br /> <br />All that being said give it a try. David Gilmouris still in top form and the songs and lyrics are good. Many complain that the lyrics are not as good as Roger Waters, but after hearing him bicker and gripe through \\"A Final Cut\\", I was glad to give Gilmour a try and you should too. After all, this record should be judged on the merit for what it is and to that end I can say that it ranks up there as a strong effort.

B0009I2LBO|5.0|This is a superlative film of suspense. It is a tribute to the direction of Alfred Hitchcock that one is never bored watching this film, though it entirely takes place within the confines of a claustrophobic New York Greenwich Village apartment, the windows of the neighbors across the way, and a courtyard that separates the buildings.<br /><br />Professional photographer L.B. \\"Jeff\\" Jeffries (Jimmy Stewart) is recovering from an accident that occurred while on assignment. Encased in a cast covering his left leg and hip, Jeff is pretty much immobilized and temporarily confined to a wheel chair. Despite regular visits by his nurse, Stella (Thelma Ritter), and his beautiful, sophisticated girlfriend, Lisa (Grace Kelly), Jeff is chafing at his confinement. Bored stiff, he does what he does best. He peers at those around him from his window. Jeff finds the lives of his neighbors both immensely interesting and amusing. He watches them through their windows and in the courtyard, enhancing his experience with binoculars and the zoom lens of his camera. Jeff draws inferences and conclusions about them, based upon his own experiences with human behavior.<br /><br />This interest intensifies and takes a strange turn, when he believes one of them, Lars Thorwald (Raymond Burr), may have committed a grisly murder, killing off his invalid wife, Anna. Though Jeff never actually sees the murder, what he does see is its aftermath and some peculiar behavior that puzzles him. Putting two and two together, he becomes absolutely convinced that his neighbor across the way has done away with his invalid wife. Jeff then informally involves his friend, Lt. Thomas Doyle (Wendell Corey) of the New York City Police Department, who initially scoffs at Jeff's assessment, though he does a cursory check . With Lisa and Stella also becoming fascinated by the strange behavior of Lars Thorwald, their interest and amateur sleuthing propels the film to an exciting climax.<br /><br />Jimmy Stewart is terrific as the housebound voyeur, drawing the viewer in with him. One finds oneself peering along with him into the lives of those around him. Grace Kelly is stunningly beautiful as Jeff's girlfriend Lisa, with whom Jeff is finding it difficult to make a commitment. It is interesting that as Jeff gets more intimately engrossed in his neighbors' affairs, his intimacy with Lisa seems to grow, drawing them closer together. Thelma Ritter is funny and sassy as the tough talking, no nonsense nurse. Raymond Burr, looking eerily as he would half a century later, is well cast as the neighbor whose wife got on his nerves. Wendell Corey is very good as the congenial, though jaded, detective.<br /><br />All in all, this is a terrific film that clearly shows the mastery and deft direction of the legendary Hitchcock. With a well written script and a stellar cast, this is a film that is well worth having in one's personal collection. Bravo!rific as the housebound voyeur, drawing the viewer in with him. One finds oneself peering along with him into the lives of those around him. Grace Kelly is stunningly beautiful as Jeff's girlfriend Lisa, with whom Jeff is finding it difficult to make a commitment. It is interesting that as Jeff gets more intimately engrossed in his neighbors' affairs, his intimacy with Lisa seems to grow, drawing them closer together. Thelma Ritter is funny and sassy as the tough talking, no nonsense nurse. Raymond Burr, looking eerily as he would half a century later, is well cast as the neighbor whose wife got on his nerves. Wendell Corey is very good as the congenial, though jaded, detective.<br /><br />All in all, this is a terrific film that clearly shows the mastery and deft direction of the legendary Hitchcock. With a well written script and a stellar cast, this is a film that is well worth having in one's personal collection. Bravo!
0201633612|5.0|The CD will work with Firefox if you install the Java 2 Runtime Environment (J2SE JRE) from Sun.
1573223026|4.0|The innovative starting point for this novel is 4 people inadvertently meet on a rooftop on New year's Eve.  Each is intent on committing suicide by jumping.  Needless to say they don't.  However, the experience causes them to form an unlikely bond and they become a \\"gang\\", meeting intermittently over the next ninety days (one learns that a researcher has theorized that the urge for suicide slacks after ninety days).    The major conflict of the book is set up immediately - these are four very distinctly different people - a middle-aged woman, a former TV star, an American rocker and a foul-mouthed teenager.  The only thing they have in common is their failed attempt at suicide.      Hornby fills the book with very good dialogue.  The story is related character by character, so that there are often overlapping perspectives on the same event.  The changing perspectives keeps the book interesting.    The characters all have depth and are believeable.  Although they at first blush appear to stereotypic, as the reader gets to know them and their most intimate thoughts, they become unique. None are particularly likeable, although the middle aged woman is sympathetic.    At about the middle of the book, it slowed as the characters got a bit bogged in excessive introspection.  It must be difficult to keep a lot of motion and action when using four depressed people to tell the story.  However, Hornby then picked the pace.      Hornby also maintains a melancholy humor throughout.  Without that humor the depressed nature of the characters' lives and moods would have been too difficult to slog through, especially since the reader never gets a \\"rooting\\" interest for any of the characters.    This is an interesting look at the characters' lives and their perspectives on their own lives as well as the others'.  Also, an interesting investigation of suicide and suicidal people.  Not a happy go lucky read, but interesting and well-written.

B000001DTM|5.0|I thoroughly enjoyed this monumental album from U2. This album was produced and constructed whilst the band were touring Germany...a nice blend of german ideas meshing with good ol' Irish ingenuity mixed with the classic lovable sound of U2. The old sound of U2 in the album was left behind. The sound of the 1980's ceased as Bono and crew decided to take the band into new territory with a more concentrated rock sound and feel. This album was initially released in 1991 and features the hit songs of 'One', 'Even Better Than The Real Thing', 'Mysterious Ways' and 'Who's Gonna Ride Your Wild Horses'. These songs mentioned are beautiful and widely known and loved by U2 fans and fans of rock music regardless. The introduction of varied synths mixed with thrumming bass brought a new deeper edge style to the already complex sound of U2. Bono and The Edge again have brought together a solid framework and all fans should be pleased by the content and result.

For me, a book is best if I forget I am reading. The writing focuses too much on its author and I was consistently aware of the style, which commands attention and could be condescending at times. I wished for a more readable book, without the occasional unnecessary, pretentious words, phrases and paragraphs. <br />The characters were very realistic and well thought out, but I still did not care much for any of them. B000002UAR|5.0|I almost had a heart attack when I saw this album only received four-and-a-half stars by customers.  This album is so good, a thousand stars would not do it justice. <br />On Revolver, the greatest band of all time reaches its apex, which by default makes it the best album ever made.  Though Sgt. Pepper gets all the press, it is its predecessor that features The Beatles crafting soaring pieces of pop music, the likes of which have never been matched. <br />By 1966, it was clear that the band had no real competition; any doubt in that notion was smashed with the release of Rubber Soul the previous year.  As a result, the two greatest songwriters in rock history, Lennon and McCartney, can only continue to compete with each other.  The result is an album so texturally refined, so brilliantly efficient, and so dazzlingly diverse that the sheer sight of the creepy album cover gives me chills. <br />From the man-or-machine countdown leading into \\"Taxman\\" to the spooky honky tonk piano ending \\"Tomorrow Never Knows\\", Revolver paints a sonic landscape unmatched in rock history.  By now, The Beatles were experimenting with tape loops and sound effects at the same rate that they were experimenting with drugs.  However, instead of overshadowing the brilliance of the songwriters' vision, they somehow make it more clear.  From classical to heavy metal; from a children's songs to a song about the joys of lying in bed; from the most gorgeous love song to the most freaked-out acid song, Revolver has it.  And it's all perfect.  <br />Though adventurous, Revolver is a very accessible album, and accessibility has always been a gift for Paul McCartney.  This album is a creative high for McCartney, the same high that Lennon achieved on Rubber Soul.  After listening to Revolver, even the most die-hard \\"Lennon-is-better-than-Paul\\" people have to look over their shoulders.  \\"Here There and Everywhere\\" is one of the most beautiful love songs ever written, and is listed as a favorite of bothJohn and Paul's.  Lyrically, McCartney is matching and even topping Lennon with two of his other masterpieces dealing with lonliness, \\"Eleanor Rigby\\" and \\"For No One\\".  Add to that the Motown swagger of \\"Got to Get You Into My Life\\" and the happy-go-lucky \\"Good Day Sunshine\\", and you have a level of mastery that Paul has never been able to match.  This is not, I believe, a discounting of McCartney's later, post-Beatle work, but rather a man who has written songs that cannot be topped, period.  McCartney also contributed the best part of John's \\"Dr. Robert\\", with it's \\"Well, well, well you're feeling fine\\" climax.  And of course, \\"Yellow Submarine\\" hums happily along. <br />Lennon, as usual, is a powerhouse who seems incapable of writing a bad song.  Even his \\"piece of garbage\\" as he described \\"And Your Bird Can Sing\\" still soars.  As a guitar player for the last 20 years, I still have trouble mastering the guitar lick for that song.  \\"She Said She Said\\" is heavy metal that still manages to be graceful and superbly melodic.  \\"I'm Only Sleeping\\" may be Lennon's best song on the album, and it's a masterpiece of melody weaved together with a lazy, easy beat and Lennon's laconic lyrical delivery.  All these perfectly extol the simple joys of dozing.  Though \\"Tomorrow Never Knows\\" probably won't be your favorite song if you're a Wings fan, it earns its praise for the relentless one-note charge that it mounts, as Paul and Ringo thump the bass and drums in syncronicity, Lennon reads his freak-out lyrics, and The Birds shriek you to your core.  (Unfortunately, one of the best songs from the Revolver period, \\"Rain\\", was the Lennon B-side to Paul's \\"Paperback Writer\\".  It's the better of the two songs, and is an overlooked Lennon classic.)    <br />Though George Harrison's \\"I Want to Tell You\\" and \\"Love You To\\" are interesting tracks, they don't measure up to the Lennon/McCartney songs.  \\"Taxman\\", on the other hand, points the path that George would take later on, crafting a song so assured (and angry) that it's clear he's been studying John and Paul's songwriting, and he proves he's a capable - if uneven - student. <br />By the end of Revolver, you feel exhausted.  The album covers so much ground and covers it so brilliantly that it seems unlikely that another album can compete.  Nearly every emotion has been shaken and stirred, and you need a drink.  The album gets under your skin as no other does.  Then, you listen to it again.
B000957O82|4.0|Since generally Will Smith is charming, versatile, and generally deserving of his celebrity status, this movie is never intolerable and is enjoyable enough the first time around.<br /><br />The problem arises when you try to watch it again.<br /><br />The main problem is the script, it seems to me, wasn't too well-thought out. What a true genius! He's surpassed pettiness and good and evil and such nonsense. It would appear that Mr. Vai is enlightened. He's the Buddha of guitar. To kneel at his feet and receive a lotus flower would be a pilgrimage worth making. Or at least a guitar pick. It takes a special dedication to be able to attain a spiritual connection with a clunky instrument like the guitar. It takes a man who starves himself of personal gratification in order to maintain a connection with the fringe of highest vibrations, the only vibrations we apes can hope to touch, and we're quite lucky to hear his results. Vai is a pioneer, a player who reaches into the darkness and comes back, maybe like Marco Polo or Lewis and Clark, and then translates reliably his interpretation of these ineffable realms. I applaud him and his efforts and am truly grateful to be alive while he's alive. This album restores my faith that there are places, and people willing to be taken to these places, where corporate principles do not yet reign supreme... beautiful places where people are not \\"dying for your loan\\"... or is it love?

B000002JSP|3.0|By the time In through the out Door was released in early 1979, it had been three years since the bands last studio effort Presence (perhaps the bands weakest effort, apart from 1982's b-side album Coda) and with Robert Plant mourning the death of his son, Jimmy Page a heavy heroin addict, & Bonzo on the brink, the album was left mainly for Zep's quiet man bass player John Paul Jones to complete, hence why the album has alot of keyboard solo's, and less Pagey solo's than past Zeppelin efforts, this in a sense is Jonesy's album!!! <br /> <br />Not to say that In through the out door is a bad album. It includes perhaps two of the bands best tracks, In the Evening (perhaps Jimmy Page's last great guitar riff) & All my Love (Robert Plant's moving tribute to his son). If anything no could accuse In through the out door of lacking direction, it has calipso (Fool in the rain) dance (Seaside Saurez, Carouselmbra) & of course rock (In the Evening, I'm gonna Crawl)!!! <br /> <br />Also although both Fool in the rain & Carouselmbra are great songs, they hardly deserve to be mentioned in the same breath as past Zeppelin efforts. Overall In through the out door turns out to be a dissapointing release compared to their past albums, but it certainly isn't their worst & though I'd never recommend it as a starting point I would definitely say if you're a big Zeppelin fan & don't have this you should buy it as it does have some great moments!!!!

B000002JSN|5.0|Physical Graffiti, released in 1975, would turn out to amazingly be Zeppelin's sixth straight classic album, with Zeppelin's I, II, II, IV & Houses of the Holy being the others. The best way to describe the album is that it has everything you would associate with Zeppelin, hard rock (The Rover, The Wanton Song, Sick Again), blues (In my time of dying, Black country woman, Boogie with Stu) funk (Custard Pie, Trampled Underfoot) there were even new sounds, the eastern influence (Kashmir, In the light) & dare I say it rock Pop (Houses of the Holy), Physical Graffiti was Zeppelin's tour de force!!! <br /> <br />So in an album, that has basically every form of rock, covered on two sides, there were the usually softer Zeppelin moments too (Ten years Gone, Down by the seaside, Night Flight). In a sense Physical Graffiti perhaps more than any other Zep album (apart from perhaps IV) show cases all of Zeppelin's talents & although not as heavy as Zeppelin's I & II and some may argue that Zep IV makes it point in half the time!!! <br /> <br />But you cannot deny Physical Graffiti's quality, or the fact that Zeppelin were one damn special band, after listening to this I wouldn't be suprised if some people started thinking Zeppelin were the next coming or something. If you want to start on a Zeppelin album, you can't really go wrong on Physical Graffiti. It's weird that the bands sixth & final classic album turns out to be one of their best!!!!

B000005DQR|5.0|1996's Entroducing by DJ Shadow introduced the concept of turntabling as a true artform. This album is constructed ENTIRELY from samples, most drawn from some truly obscure sources, shaped into its own unique and brilliant entity.<br /><br />It kicks off with Best Foot Forward, basically a scratch-heavy intro before going into the brilliant Building Steam With A Grain Of Salt, a moody slow-burning groove that paints images of steady rain out the window of a darkened downtown corner. Truly mesmerizing. The rest of the album offers up nonstop brilliance. Ambient? Jazz? R&B/soul? Hip-hop? Rock? It's all in there, constantly filtered through Shadow's boundless ingenuity and woven into sonic collages that are ample evidence of the fact that truly great composition transcends the boundaries of genre.<br /><br />From a charging funk track (The Numbers Song) to an dark soundscape with lots of twists and turns (Stem/Long Stem), Endtroducing is always engaging. Melancholy, hopeful, intelligent, and witty, occassionally all at the same time. Timeless.
B000002J03|5.0|Led Zeppelin II follows on from the heaviness of their previous LP, but oddly it is far more accessable than the first & if anything is their most commercial release (well as commercial as Zeppelin can get) as many of the tracks don't go over the 5 minute mark. So with 9 tracks to listen to in a 39 minute period is Led Zeppelin II Zeps radio friendly album??? Well if you think it is...you don't know Zep!!!! <br /> <br />The album begins with the US smash single (actually the bands biggest hit single) Whole Lotta Love, a song that borrows lyrics from Willie Nelson, but who cares, it's not like Zep are the first ones to do this & def. not the last. Whilst Thank You is beautiful, & is Robert Plants tribute to his then wife, & was a sign of things to come on III. Heartbreaker is class, whilst Living loving Maid is pure fun. Ramble on is an accoustic number, but even here Zep sound heavy, whilst Moby Dick has one of the greatest drum solos you'll ever hear & Bring it on home (a cover of a Willie Dixon song) ends the album on a bluesy boogie!!! <br /> <br />To conclude Led Zeppelin II is the easiest & most accessable Zeppelin album. 0553582461|2.0|Robin Hobb has an unquestionable position at the pinnacle of speculative fiction, having written not the one but the two best fantasy trilogies of the last generation.  And even in the first two books of the Tawny Man trilogy she kept up a quite high standard.  But something happened on the way to the conclusion.  For sure \\"Fool's Fate\\" reads like a Robin Hobb novel.  The dialogue is intelligent, the characters astonishingly real, the world-building careful and solid, and the writing good at a technical level.  At a deeper level, however, Hobb has completely lost sight of what makes a good story.<br /><br />The best I can say for \\"Fool's Fate\\" is that it's a nine-hundred page book which may have a decent three-hundred page book lurking somewhere inside.  We left on in \\"Golden Fool\\" with our heroes anticipating their upcoming quest to slay the dragon Icefyre.  In \\"Fool's Fate\\" they spend one hundred pages at Buckkeep packing and preparing, one hundred pages sailing to the Out Islands, one hundred pages dithering around on an island, and another hundred dithering on a different island.  Four hundred pages gone before the plot is really in motion.<br /><br />We often fear that successful authors simply include anything that comes into their head, and their editors aren't brave enough to hack off unwarranted text.  Sadly that's exactly the case here.  One obvious example: Fitz taking care of Thick.  This consumes well over a hundred pages, with Fitz feeding Thick, dressing Thick, watching Thick be seasick, dragging Thick onto ships, arguing with Thick, fighting with Thick, etc...  This hits the crux of the problem with \\"Fool's Fate\\".  Hobb wants to say things that are true regardless of whether they're interesting.  So yes, of course retarded people were often abused and mistreated in past eras and yes a good person should treated the mentally challenged with respect.  But watching Fitz nursemaid Thick is like reading a novel about paint drying.  Needless to say Thick ends up doing something important at the end and thus justifying his presence on the quest.  But his role is trivially small.  Hobb could have written Thick out of the book entirely, and should have.  Like Jar Jar Binks, he single-handedly turns a decent artwork into a lousy one just by existing.<br /><br />Thick, though, is merely a victim of a larger disease: the dreaded bloat.  Conversations go on ten pages, fifteen pages, or more.  We see events that have no place in the story, visit places we don't need to see, hear the same thoughts repeated over and over.  We get a list of every character's emotions and facial expressions at every paragraph.<br /><br />Even after all this, \\"Fool's Fate\\" might have been redeemed by a good climactic showdown.  But that flops too.  The largest problem with the entire Tawny Man Trilogy is that the villains are so lame.  Laudwine was a paper tiger.  The new villainess in \\"Fool's Fate\\" is a horrendous cliche straight out of a Terry Goodkind novel: evil, laughs maniacally, sex-crazed, tortures people for no particular reason.<br /><br />Ultimately \\"Fool's Fate\\" collapses due to lack of planning and self-control.  Without a goal worth caring about, without progression towards a well-defined conclusion, there's just no reason to keep reading.  Several times I was on the verge of giving up; were this written by any other author, I most likely would have.  We can only hope that Hobb will get back on track with her next project.ck ends up doing something important at the end and thus justifying his presence on the quest.  But his role is trivially small.  Hobb could have written Thick out of the book entirely, and should have.  Like Jar Jar Binks, he single-handedly turns a decent artwork into a lousy one just by existing. <br /> <br />Thick, though, is merely a victim of a larger disease: the dreaded bloat.  Conversations go on ten pages, fifteen pages, or more.  We see events that have no place in the story, visit places we don't need to see, hear the same thoughts repeated over and over.  We get a list of every character's emotions and facial expressions at every paragraph. <br /> <br />Even after all this, \\"Fool's Fate\\" might have been redeemed by a good climactic showdown.  But that flops too.  The largest problem with the entire Tawny Man Trilogy is that the villains are so lame.  Laudwine was a paper tiger.  The new villainess in \\"Fool's Fate\\" is a horrendous cliche straight out of a Terry Goodkind novel: evil, laughs maniacally, sex-crazed, tortures people for no particular reason. <br /> <br />Ultimately \\"Fool's Fate\\" collapses due to lack of planning and self-control.  Without a goal worth caring about, without progression towards a well-defined conclusion, there's just no reason to keep reading.  Several times I was on the verge of giving up; were this written by any other author, I most likely would have.  We can only hope that Hobb will get back on track with her next project.

B000002JSR|2.0|When Led Zeppelin split in 1980 thanks to the untimely death of drummer John Bonham (aka Bonzo) around a year later Jimmy Page went back into the studio and grafted out all the so called remaining Led Zep songs that had been recorded. Some were from as early as 1969, and might have been for Led Zeppelin II (We're gonna groove, Poor) there were also some for Led Zep III (Walters Walk, which is included as an instrumental performance in the bands excellent How the west was Won live album) and the others sessions just after 1979, up to just before the band split (Ozone Baby, Darlene, & Wearing & Tearing). <br /> <br />Although there are some excellent tunes (We're gonna Groove, Darlene & Wearing & Tearing) there are still some questions left unanswered. First why aren't there more songs, why is Hey, hey what can I do (a non-lp b-side to the single Immigrant Song) not on this album. Also there are others that should have been included too such as Baby come on Home. Also although the live version of I can't quit you baby is great couldn't this have been saved for a live release!!! <br /> <br />Overall Coda, released eventually in 1982, is a big dissapointment, considering the bands back catelogue. Though I wouldn't recommend it to first time listeners, I would say if you're a Led Zep fan who has Led Zep albums I-In through the out door then definitely buy this, as it's essential for completists. B0007XT87G|5.0|Porcupine Tree started off as Steven Wilson's \\"great lost progressive rock band\\" joke and turned into something entirely more, as Wilson has evolved the band and the music.  One thing I've always said about really great bands, I don't like everything they do.  This is because for me, great bands take chances, and taking chances means sometimes something isn't going to work for a fan.  And in fact, I had all but lost interest in Porcupine Tree before \\"Deadwing\\" came out.  But for some reason, I decided to give the album a chance. <br /> <br />Certainly, that was one of the better ideas I've had recently.    \\"Deadwing\\" is fantastic-- not quite the masterpiece I thought \\"Signify\\" was, but it's awfully good.  The album is a concept of sorts-- Wilson and a partner wrote a screenplay to a movie, loosely a ghost story about self-discovery, and wrote the album about the movie.  This lends a sense of unity to the album that I think has been missing on the past couple Porcupine Tree releases.  It takes the heaviness of \\"In Absentia\\", fuses it with the pop sensibilities of \\"Stupid Dream\\" and the brilliant arrangements and style of \\"Signify\\".  What perhaps is most telling is that several of the songs are really quite long (three stretch around 10 minutes+), but none of them FEEL long-- they're organic and natural and they flow well. <br /> <br />One thing to note about the album though is that it is strong as an album statement and lacks a lot of highlights on a moment-by-moment basis-- certainly guest guitarist Adrian Belew's fierce soloing on the title track and \\"Halo\\" is notable, and \\"Mellotron Scratch\\" is pretty clever, well arranged, and features the best synth blast I've heard on record, but really the album itself makes the statement.  The exception to this is \\"Lazarus\\".  Perhaps Wilson's finest moment as a songwriter, it's delicate ballad with a circular piano line, a superb soft vocal, and a sublime slide guitar line.  Really, it stands amongst the best songs I've heard in quite a long time.  And the truth really is that \\"Lazarus\\" alone is worth the price of the album, the fact the rest of it is awfully good is a bonus.  Essential listening for fans and otherwise, check this one out.
B00005JMAH|5.0|Once again, thanks for the great deal as well as the great purchase.
006441034X|4.0|I hadn't read any of Diana Wynne Jones' books before I'd watched Miyazaki's take on Howl's Moving Castle.  It seemed that the movie had left out certain plot points leaving it a bit on the confusing side.  So, I picked up the book, curious. <br /> <br />Overall, I enjoyed reading this book.  It is certainly a good book for young adults or readers who enjoy fantasy books such as Brian Jacques' Redwall.  There are many wonderfully created events and experiences that are sure to delight. <br /> <br />More advanced readers will find that it lacks a continuous driving dramatic plot.  There isn't quite the rising action and climax as all excellent fiction has.  It does have a climax, but we don't see it coming till nearly the very end, when it just seems to happen. <br /> <br />The changes in the movie contain a rising action for the plot.  It does increase the danger and excitement in the viewer, whereas the book does not. <br /> <br />Oddly, the book and movie together create something that compliments both and further explains and fleshes out the story and characters.   <br /> <br />Regardless, I'd wholly recommend this book to anyone who enjoys fantasy and a good story.

0385338082|5.0|I LOVED THIS BOOK.  I've recommended this book to many of my girl friends, and they have all loved with as much enthusiasm. One of the greatest way to spend your free time reading this book, and, unlike the plethora of those books that are great but so difficult to get into at first, Can You Keep A Secret pulls you right in at the start.  Emma works as a marketer in a huge company, but actually doesn't know what she's doing...which is refreshing.  You know right off that she's honest and it's so easy to love her.  Anyway--she just failed her first important business meeting and is now faced with her flight back, which turns out even more scary than her failed meeting.  Emma's already terrified of flying, and to make it worse, the plane hits some bad turbulence.  Thinking that she's going to die, she panics and pours out her life story along with all its humiliating bits to the innocent man sitting next to her.  However, they end up making it just fine, and Emma pushes the whole thing out of her mind.  But come Monday, her company gets an unexpected visit from the CEO...which to Emma's horror, turns out to be the exact same guy who was sitting next to her on the plane--the guy that now knows all the intimate, embarrassing details of her life. <br /> <br />And the fun starts there! <br /> <br />Seriously, this is a great read.  Although its shallow and the plot is not that extravagant, Kinsella's story telling ability is marvelous.  Emma has a strong, well-defined voice.  Nothing feels contrived.  She's very frank and candid, admits to giving into luxuries, doesn't like her coworkers, is not perfect (but hell, who is?) and that is what makes her so endearing.  I read a lot of \\"serious\\" books for pleasure too, not just chic-lit, and I still loved this.  Out of all the British chic-lit I've read, this so far has proven to be the best. <br /> <br />(This was the first novel I read by Sophie Kinsella.  I tried reading her shopaholic series afterwards, but I don't think they're nearly as good.  Shopaholic wasn't as funny and...it just didn't do it for me.  Can You Keep A Secret is much better.)

B00005Q4CS|5.0|Much is often mentioned of this film's depiction of drugs and the people addicted to them. To focus one's criticism solely on the negative depiction of drugs in this film is a shallow interpretation of what is ultimately a movie about addiction in all of its forms, even the seemingly 'harmless' addictions of common people. From a TV set, a box of chocolates, the exploration of intimacy between lovers, or the need to be accepted among peers, There's much lurking beneath the surface of this film that is unsettling with regards to human desires, and the lengths to which people go to achieve them.  <br /> <br />What I found most fascinating about this film, was Ellen Burstyn's portrayal of a lonely widow, who after receiving a phone call from a telemarketer promising her an appearance on a television show, becomes slowly obsessed with trying to fit her overweight body into a red dress. What starts as a diet, slowly devolves into a pill popping nightmare, which decays even further into hallucinations and neurosis to the extent that her refrigerator emerges as a monstrous entity slowly preying on her fragile sanity. <br /> <br />Where some found this movie to be disturbing, I found it to be spellbinding. The photography was amazing and the overall film has a meticulously 'crafted' look to it. Darren Aronofsky's inspired use of split screen, clever editing cuts and motion speeds elevate the film visually to the point that your eyes are actually drawn to what at times, can be some fairly repulsive images.  <br /> <br />The soundtrack punched me in the chest the first time I heard it. The central cellos grinding their melody over various ambient sounds, beats and orchestral rhythms was truly unique. Since this film's release, i have heard its soundtrack used on trailers for other movies (most notably, 'LOTR: The Return of the King' TV spots). <br /> <br />I would never say that this film is for everyone. It seems like a movie people tend to either love or hate. I'd be amazedto find anyone 'riding the fence' in their opinion of this movie. I'm obviously one who loves this movie. I was completely amazed by the look, sound and feel of this film. Ellen Burstyn gave the performance of her life in this film, which is really just one bullet point on a movie which i found to be brilliant in numerous ways, from start to finish.

0060723513|3.0|To understand the genre of this book's concept, think Carlos Castaneda and his mysti-speak Yaqui yarns. Since I am part Native American (Cherokee), married to a Samoan over 40 years, having lived and traveled among relatively \\"uncivilized\\" peoples for many years, I understand how an idealistic non-Aborigine could have thought that to spin this story would be a good idea. But native peoples themselves tend to understand their world quite differently from how overconfident outsiders think they do. Thus much of even Margaret Mead's professional anthropological study, Coming of Age in Samoa (most of which was not fiction as is Morgan's novel), caused both ire and mirth among Samoans, who recognized that various of Mead's case studies were spun, and others were based on Samoans' playing straight-faced jokes on her that she didn't catch onto before publication. <br /> <br />I sympathize and resonate with Morgan's intent of giving voice to Aborigine views and sentiments that we need in our increasingly technologically polluted world, but she got so much wrong that Aboriginal elders became incensed enough to make a transoceanic journey in order to protest a proposed film to be made from the book, and extracted an apology from Morgan regarding her untruthful and/or simply ignorant claims. <br /> <br />The book is interesting and readable despite Morgan's weaknesses as a writer, and one of my sons, a bonified lizard lover who has lived barefoot in that part of the world, loves it. If you read it, think of it as allegorical and colorful, like a brightly painted hippy bus of the 60s, and be open to its \\"spiritual\\" thought content, but don't mistakenly think of it as being an account of actual experiences. Again, think Carlos Castaneda with his wacky Yaqui sorcerer guide.

0380789035|5.0|The gods are born by the human decision to worship them, live as long as they are remembered, and die if they are forgotten: The idea is at least as old as Richard Garnett's \\"Twilight of the Gods\\" short story. So what happens to gods when they become casual memories, no longer worshipped but lingering at the edge of consciousness?<br /><br />Gaiman would suggest that Odin is the oldest American god who has not passed entirely from our memory, having arrived with the first Viking visitors (unless Gaiman is doing a bit more with prehistory and that mammoth skull than I caught in one reading; I *think* that god is dead). He's also going to let us know {warning: very slight spoiler} that the American Odin is not the same as the Scandanavian one, though they were once the same (new conceptions of the gods become, in effect, new and separate gods).<br /><br />So we know the old gods, Odin and all the rest of those folks from a variety of traditions. And we meet a few of the new gods, like the TV set and the 'net and 'Media' and maybe Elvis (a fun touch: do we meet Elvis or not? Gaiman does mention his name).<br /><br />The plot? Oh, these gods are going to have a war, and our protagonist is going to find himself in the middle of it. That, and a subplot or two, serves to hold our interest as Gaiman invites us to join in his cynical reflection on American values: What are our gods? Do we have any who are worth our thoughts, let alone our worship?<br /><br />On the surface it's a good story, an intriguing fantasy piece with a cynical message. It also has a bit of depth -- the protagonist is named 'Shadow' with good reason, and more shadows than him lurk in the background of this book.
B00005OWEG|5.0|Roger Ebert's original review of \\"Apocalypse Now\\" predicted that once the circumstances of the nightmarish shoot were forgotten, and once the debate over Marlon Brando's million dollar salary died down, all that would be left was one of the most powerful, vivid movies ever made.  That was before Francis Ford Coppola and Walter Murch finally remade the movie more than two decades later. <br /> <br />\\"Hearts of Darkness: A Filmmaker's Apocalypse\\" has been released, giving viewers more insight into just what happened in the Philippines.  And Jim Carrey made a reported 20 million dollars to make \\"The Cable Guy\\", for which we will never see a Redux.  So, with controversy out of the way, is Ebert right? <br /> <br />I believe the extra 49 minutes of footage are carefully and organically sewn into \\"Apocalypse Now -- Redux\\".  If anything, they make the movie more coherent.  They turn Coppola's disjointed nightmare into a fever dream that makes sense.  While some moments in \\"Redux\\" have drawn criticism, I found that each had some merit in fleshing out the theatrical release. <br /> <br />\\"Redux\\" adds one final episode before Captain Willard reaches Kurtz's compound: the visit to a French plantation that appears out of the fog.  I read somewhere that Coppola considered the French characters to be ghosts.  This makes perfect sense.  There are nearly identical shots of the boat before and after this scene; one could imagine that it never really happened, apart from in Willard's fevered imagination, or Lance's acid-tinged haze. <br /> <br />Dialogue in that scene compares the Vietnam War to \\"the biggest nothing in history\\", a point that hearkens back nicely to \\"Heart of Darkness\\".  The plantation owner's chart of the number of attacks he defended against -- from Vietnam North and South, and from the Americans -- grounds the scene deeply in the illogic of war.  Did John \\"Red Dawn\\" Milius really write that sequence? <br /> <br />As for the extended Playmates sequence... say what you will about the disconcerting tryst between Frederic Forrest and the bird-loving Miss December (Miss May!), but you can point a finger at Sam Bottoms and say this is exactly the scene where Lance loses touch with reality; his fixation with camouflage paint begins here, and he hardly utters a word for the rest of the film.  This adds texture to his mute surrender to Kurtz's children. <br /> <br />By the time Marlon Brando appears, the movie has already made its point countless times over: in the number of soldiers who don't know who's in charge; in Albert Hall's eyes, after the expressively rigid boat chief is surprised to find that he's dead; in Robert Duvall's comic lament to his stolen surfboard (\\"You know how hard it is to find a board you like\\"); in the realization that the U.S. Army has \\"liberated\\" villages from merely a phantom menace that never really appears in the film.  If the film had concluded without Willard ever finding Kurtz, this movie would still have made its mark as one of the great movies about war and its effect on human nature.

B0002OERI0|5.0|I have long followed rock music and feel that Green Day has produced a strong contender for the greatest rock album of all time.  In my mind, it is the greatest.  Concept albums are ambitious undertakings, held together by simple stories and mostly with little meaning or message to glean from.  Green Day has come up with a concept album, a punk rock opera, that has powerful political and cultural relevance, beautiful yet profound lyrics, terrific style with breakout songs ranging from powerful ballads like \\"Boulevard of Broken Dreams\\"and \\"Wake Me Up When September Ends\\" to hard rock classics like \\"American Idiot\\" and \\"Holiday\\" and two nine-minute mini-masterpieces composed of five different parts each. <br /> <br />What Green Day has done so brilliantly is to tackle the ever-present state of apathy and the erosion of our essential freedoms by conservatism and the \\"redneck agenda\\".  They relay these messages through the eyes of a young disaffected youth, the Jesus of Suburbia, who experiences a sudden awakening and challenges the spoon-fed morals and values tossed at him by politicians and the media.  He struggles with rage and love, encountering strong personalities along the way in the suicidial and nihilistic St. Jimmy (who could be his alter ego or even a figment of his imagination) and the righteous independent girl Whatshername.  The album doesn't settle for a predictable and expected happy ending but leaves it open-ended and reflective, just as life often is. <br /> <br />The brilliantly conceived lyrics are both poetic and illusory, allowing for much speculation and interpretation.  Nothing is completely obvious or pedantic.  And yet beneath it all lie powerful messages about apathy, homophobia, censorship, the media, materialism, religion and war.   <br /> <br />Billie Joe Armstrong's great sense of catchy hooks combined with the phenomenally powerful and propulsive drumming of Tre Cool and the perfectly matched basslines, like a deep and low heartbeat, fromthe equally talented Mike Dirnt work so well on the potent rock anthems and ballads.  There's not a better trio in rock today. <br /> <br />Green Day doesn't limit their style to one form of music but instead explores punk, rock and musicals.  Their influences include the Rolling Stones, Motown, Queen, Led Zeppelin, The Clash and the Sex Pistols as well as the musicals The Rocky Horror Picture Show, Grease and Jesus Christ Superstar.   <br /> <br />Any lover of rock music must appreciate Jesus of Suburbia and Homecoming.  Each song is basically composed of five different tunes, each one unique and blending into the next.  It is amazing to pull off a song like this once.  But they did it twice in the same album. <br /> <br />All the musical transitions work well in bridging the songs and keeping the story going.  And there are innovative uses of the glockenspiel, church bells and bongos. <br /> <br />Even the artwork has a power and beauty, a symbolic fist grabbing a heart in the shape of a hand grenade, representing the struggle between rage and love. <br /> <br />This great great album has a cross-generational appeal that spans from young children to those in their fifties.  It has won over so many fans who never sampled Green Day before.  Bravo bravo bravo to Green Day.  I do not envy them having to follow up on this masterpiece.
